Corruption and street crime were rampant. It was far from paradise.This grittiness, however, inspired some fine movie-making which perfectly captured the atmosphere and culture in the Big City. With its frantic pace and frenzied intensity, The Taking of Pelham One Two Three represents such an effort. It boasts a fine cast and is well-directed. It features an outstanding score by composer David Shire. And it proves that action-thrillers can indeed be effective without massive budgets and an over-reliance on special effects.Four criminals code named Mr. Blue, Mr. Green, Mr. Brown and Mr. Grey mastermind the hijacking of an NYC subway train. Detaching a single car holding seventeen people, they demand one million dollars from the city, threatening to shoot one hostage for each minute the money is late. NY Transit Lieutenant Zachary Garber (Walter Matthau) is tasked with handling the crisis and communicating directly with their leader, the ruthless Mr. Blue (Robert Shaw). Garber is the quintessential New Yorker; cynical yet quick on his feet. With the help of Police Captain Rico Petrone (Jerry Stiller), he matches wits with the criminals in an effort to deliver the money, save the hostages and identify and apprehend the hijackers.The movie never drags and keeps us guessing. Despite its serious theme, Pelham has comedic elements- most notably Garber's early dealings with a visiting Japanese transportation delegation and his interplay with a Head Dispatcher (Dick O'Neill) more concerned with keeping his trains running on time than he is with a hostage crisis. Also funny are scenes with the neurotic Mayor of New York trying to gather the ransom by the deadline. It mirrors the buffoonery of many real life politicians unable to effectively handle a crisis and accurately reflects the very real money woes NYC had at the time.Matthau, Shaw, Stiller & O'Neill all perform their roles well, as do Martin Balsam and Hector Elizondo- two members of the heist crew. And The Taking of Pelham also has maybe the best ending I've ever seen in a film. A super movie. Highly recommended.

Four men hold the passengers of a NYC subway car for ransom, demanding a million dollars in an hour or the hostages start dying. Mathau is wonderful as a transit cop who negotiates with the bad guys. There's a funny bit where he hurls mild insults at visiting Japanese metro officials thinking they don't understand English. Also fine are Shaw and Balsam as two of the villains. Though implausible, the film is quite entertaining, as the suspense builds and reaches a satisfactory if unspectacular climax. Sargent, a veteran of TV, keeps the plot moving at a rapid pace, maintaining a sense of excitement. The supporting cast is peppered with familiar faces.

Ex-mercenary Robert Shaw and his colour-coded crew take over the titular subway train full of New York City stereotypes and demand one million dollars in exchange for the release of the hostages. With the clock ticking and the Big Apple's dysfunctional civic government bickering, the intrepid Transit Authority cops (led by Lt. Zach Garber; Walter Matthau) try to figure out how the crooks plan to escape from the sealed up tunnel. The cast is very good and the script excellent, with lots of droll comments from Matthau and ice-cold politeness from Shaw and the two leads' laconic deliveries are an amusing counterpoint to the noisy tumult that is excited 'New Yawkers'. All in all, an entertaining story and great flashback to early '70's cop thrillers. The colourful 'noms de crime' were the inspiration for Mr. Orange et al. in Quentin Tarantino's great "Reservoir Dogs' (1992).

One of the things that I didn't expect was the HUMOR in THE TAKING OF PELHAM 123: it's off the rails. Walter Matthau was capable of dire drama (see the original FAIL-SAFE) as well as side-splitting comedy (see THE ODD COUPLE); in THE TAKING OF PELHAM 123, he indulges in a bit of BOTH. While everyone around him seems to be taking things in stride (more or less), his character gets caught up in the gravity of the situation early on. Even so, he seems to have a fatalistic sense of humor about it all (though he never belittles the kidnappers or openly makes light of them or the situation); it's a well-balanced performance by a man who's at the top of his game. I enjoyed the remake just as much as this version, but the humor here caught me by surprise.

First, let me say that this cast is just too notch. Lots of great over the top language that makes you laugh and love the characters even more. It definitely kicks off with a bang about 5 minutes in and then you're hooked! How could four men rob a subway train in a tunnel and get away with the proposed $1 million dollars?The action never stops and how it's filmed / shot is very fast paced as we flip from the subway to the New York police headquarters very often.Highly recommend if you are looking for an edgy / fast paced action, comedy, drama!

THE TAKING OF PELHAM ONE TWO THREE is a very 1970s heist thriller which means it's dated watching it in 2010 . This is in no way a criticism and truth be told makes it more enjoyable in contemporary times where no one is allowed to upset anyone . Remember Sidney Lumet's heist thriller THE ANDERSON TAPES with its homophobic wisecracks ? PELHAM reinforces what would probably qualify as " hate crime " amongst humourless critics have probably never cracked a joke or a smile in their entire life . PELHAM is awash with New York City stereotypes and ethnic groups which leads to some witty and funny scenes such as Lt Graber referring to a Japanese guided tour party as " A bunch of Jap monkeys " only to have their leader thank him in English . All New Yorkers are loud self centered and the most common job amongst women is prostitution and all Jews are only interested in money:" Excuse me sir do you mind me asking how much you're getting ? " " A million dollars " Oi vey that's not so good " The dialogue by Peter Stone is so enjoyable that the main plot of the heist itself is secondary . It's also interesting to note that the villains give themselves code names involving colours , an idea that Taratino referenced blatantly in RESERVIOR DOGS All in all this is a very enjoyable thriller mainly down to the fact that in the 1970s no one who produced a movie thought along the lines of " Oh we'd better not say that in case we upset anyone " . In my view the only crime a film maker can do is fail to entertain the audience

I did not know that I have missed such a great movie so far. I read the reviews of this movie and also knew there is a remake coming this year with Denzel W. I wanted to see the original flick first (this one). This is a kind of movie I wanted to see in a long time! No unnecessary plot developments and story begins immediately. And it picks up pace as it goes along. All the characters are natural and strong, an important thing that we miss in todays movies which are bloated with fake expressions and lingo-jingos.The movie doesn't boast a huge cast but you couldn't notice any bad performance by even supporting artists. No spectacular visual effects or gun-firing but brilliant screenplay keeps you occupied and the editing is so good that there is no single scene that is unnecessary to the movie. Very good classic that has been under-rated.

reviews.review_title: The Taking of Pelham One Two Three
reviews.content: I had heard about this film from the Channel 5 countdown of Greatest Disaster Movies (it isn't a disaster movie!), and it looked quite interesting, so I gave it a go. Basically four men, leader Mr. Blue (Robert Shaw), Mr. Green (Psycho's Martin Balsam), Mr. Grey (Hector Elizondo) and Mr. Brown (Earl Hindman) hijack a New York subway train. On the radio they give demands to transport cop Lt. Zachary 'Z' Garber (Walter Matthau), they want $1,000,000 from the Mayor (Batman's Lee Wallace, he is the Mayor in that too), and they have only one hour to deliver it. If they are a minute late, they start killing one hostage (they've got 18) every minute they are overdue. They agree to pay the ransom, and they manage to get off with the train running, and in the end, Mr. Blue electrocutes himself on the train tracks, Mr. Grey and Mr. Brown are gunned down, and the only one that gets away, Mr. Green, is caught by Garber (who managed to gather information about criminals that can drive trains, running it down to nine names, and Green's one of them) when he recognises his sneeze, after saying "gesundheit". Also starring James Broderick as Denny Doyle, Dick O'Neill as Frank Correll, Tom Pedi as Caz Dolowicz, Beatrice Winde as Mrs. Jenkins, Jerry Stiller as Lt. Rico Patrone and Live and Let Die's Julius Harris as Inspector Daniels. It is like an early version of Speed, the anonymous colour code names were obviously borrowed for Reservoir Dogs, and it a well paced, well edited, well acted thrill ride. Very good!

I seem to get a bigger kick out of Walter M. in his more serious roles, and this was no exception. A very good film with lots of action, thrills, and drama. Robert Shaw turns in his usual villainous performance as the ruthless Blue. Although this could be termed just another action film, as it is, it still brings home the bacon as a nerve jittering tale. Thumbs up.

reviews.review_title: The Greatest Heist Film Ever Made. Full Stop.
reviews.content: Known mostly for television dramas, The Taking Of Pelham 123 is Joseph Sargent's unexpected magnus opus.The perfect blend of gritty New York crime film, actioner and comedy, rolled into one, it succeeds on virtually every front where other heist films fail.And, to this day, it retains it's position as the greatest heist film ever made.Not to mention one of the most iconic films ever set in New York City.Based on Brooklyn resident Morton Freedgood's novel (written under his pen name John Godey) of the same name, and adapted for the screen by Peter Stone, the story, characters, and realism of the film are captured to absolute perfection.Though painted with a comedic edge, from the cops, to the capers, to the politicians, and even the subway attendants, and hostages, all the characters are flawed in a believably human way.With performances by Matthau, and Robert Shaw, particularly standing out...the entire cast does a standout job in all the roles throughout the film...no matter how big or small they are.An education in casting, if I have ever seen it.The story, on top of being a masterful blend of heist flick, thriller, actioner, and detective comedy-drama...would go on to influence a plethora of films in the crime genre.Most notably Reservoir Dogs (colour coded names) and Takers (subway pirate aspect)...two heist films which, in themselves, are also among the best of the genre.But what really makes this film sit head over heels above the rest is the realism of the plot and characters.The flawed nature of the characters, in combination with the mistakes made on every front, make for an especially enjoyable experience.Because no matter who you are, you can just resonate with the characters in this sort of situation.The New Yorkers are good people at heart, even when flawed by racism and ignorance. The villains are villainous. And the cops are as stupid and cowardous as any real cop you'll ever meet.On top of this, the plot revolves around a technical aspect, that hasn't been seen since Rififi, and later films like Mission Impossible and Thomas Crowne Affair (remake) would only live up to.And to fashion an inherently anti-heroic character like a transit authority cop as the hero, above all others in the film, is just golden.It would go on to spawn to remakes of it's own as well...a made for tv movie in the late 90's and full film remake in the 2010's.Not even films like The Italian Job or Lock Stock and Two Smoking Barrels managed to raise themselves to the bar that this film has set, despite their own greatness.It's plain and simply, the greatest heist film ever made...and an underrated masterpiece.Full Stop.10 out of 10.

reviews.review_title: A great film about a tough city .....
reviews.content: Dear George Carlin,in one of your shows you spoke about how New York is the toughest city in America and if a hurricane ever came to New York it would show the hurricane its middle finger.Well, The Taking of Pelham 123 is the quintessential New York film I guess. It is about the people who run the city's subway system and how they handle a hostage situation. The film is full of badass characters who don't blink an eyelid even when they learn that a train has been hijacked. John Godey and Peter Stone deserve special mention for writing some really clever, funny and politically incorrect dialog. The dialog really helped in emphasizing the city's tough third world culture that you spoke about, George. The dialog really made this movie. The action mostly takes place inside the train and the offices of the people who run the system.Walter Matthau is effortlessly cool as an efficient detective. The scene where he takes the visiting Japanese officials around was very funny.A terrific rip roaring score by David Shire is perfect for the film's tough characters but it is underused.Best Regards, Pimpin.(8/10)

reviews.review_title: My Second Favorite Movie Of The 1970's
reviews.content: I try to avoid using words like "the Best" when it comes to movies since it is all so subjective. I feel much more comfortable and poised discussing my personal favorites, and why I love them. Walter Matthau is virtually ideal as the world-weary and sarcastic New York police detective. Capable of interjecting quick wit into the most morbid situations and equally capable of committing numerous faux pas, he nonetheless NEVER loses his humanity and does not let fear of ridicule deter him from taking care of the business at hand. I have never seen a movie portray a cop that, at the same time, is so realistic as a human being, entertaining as a character, and effective as a detective despite inevitable false starts. There is not a false note in Matthau's performance.As a perfect complement to Matthau's tour-de-force, the quartet of crooks (Shaw, Elizondo, Balsam, and Hindman) all present facades of coldly and brutally efficient professionalism as robbers-by-choice but murderers-only-by-necessity. Shaw and Elizondo are superb with the two showier roles, but they are made even more effective by the underplayed professional support supplied by Hindman and Balsam. The latter contributes mightily to the film's unforgettable final scene.The plot, music, photography, background, dialog, and the rest of the supporting cast -- most especially Dick O'Neill as a vengeful city worker, Lee Wallace as the whiny mayor, and Tony Roberts as Wallace's image consultant -- are all equally up to the task.I love many 1970's movies. Probably not coincidentally, my #1 favorite remains the Sting, another caper movie. Some of my other favorites that still hold up well today include: Rocky, Sleuth, Patton, M*A*S*H, One Flew Over The Cuckoo's Nest, American Graffiti, Paper Moon, Kramer Vs. Kramer, Star Wars, Taxi Driver, Fiddler On The Roof, Brian's Song, The Godfather, The Last Detail, and Cabaret. Nevertheless, if I'm alone on a rainy day here in New York City, and wish to be entertained, frequently the first movie I will select is The Taking Of Pelham-One-Two-Three.

I would never have stumbled on this film were it not for the countless remakes it has had since its 1974 original release.It is a simple hijacking caper on a New York City subway train starring Walter Matthau as transit cop Lt. Zach Gaber and Robert Shaw as maniac henchman Bernard Ryder aka Blue.Shaw is very much Red Grant off From Russia With Love (minus the blonde hair colour) rather than crazy fisherman Quint off Jaws.The movie shows all the seventies grime of New York City and it's largest subway system in the world to boot!The film features 17 hostages and a cast of various stereotypes along with some script writing that would never pass politically correct censorship today.A big thing is constantly made by the mayor and police of the $1million ransom demand as if it is going to bankrupt the city! Haven't they realised that after inflation it looks relatively good value today!The cat and mouse games between Matthau and Shaw are a highlight. Two great actors.The look on both their faces. Matthau in the final frame and Shaw after electrocuting himself on the live third line are great freeze frames.Films just aren't made as enjoyable as this any more. Oh and no CGI in sight.

reviews.review_title: They're gonna fly the train to Cuba!
reviews.content: One of the best thrillers of the 1970s, this gritty urban thriller concerns itself with four extremely dangerous men, led by an incredibly ruthless Robert Shaw, holding seventeen passengers and a conductor hostage on a New York subway train.  They phone in their threat at 2:13 P.M., giving the city of New York exactly (and I do mean EXACTLY) one hour to deliver a million-dollar ransom or, starting at 3:13, they will begin executing one hostage for every minute the money is late.  It is up to a hard-nosed transit cop (the late, great Walter Matthau) to work his way out of this problem while dealing with, among other things, a loud and foul-mouthed boss (Dick O'Neill).Shaw and Matthau are extremely well-matched adversaries, and there is plenty of hilarious humor and profanity on display here.  Joseph Sargent, who directed the underrated 1970 sci-fi drama COLOSSUS: THE FORBIN PROJECT, directs very efficiently once again; and David Shire's score is top-notch. Not to be missed, especially since it is a precursor to the DIE HARD movies and off-shoots like SPEED.

reviews.review_title: It was good enough for Tarantino
reviews.content: The best thing about watching Pelham in 2001 is seeing how many directors have managed to pay homage to it since 1974.  Sure Tarantino lifted the color coding of the principles in "Reservoir Dogs" yet Joseph Sargent's expression of the crooks as an organized military unit has been a staple of solid crime films since.  Perhaps building on the smooth style of Robert Vaughn from his days working on "Man from U.N.C.L.E.", Sargent has Robert Shaw (Mr. Blue) playing the police like a drum until Mr. Grey throws a wrench into the system.  The classic struggle between the "intelligent" versus the "barbaric" villain has played itself out in countless films since.  In classic 70's style, this straight forward film is fast moving and doesn't waste a scene.  Each character is developed enough to fit their role in the story and not a bit more.  Peter Stone's writing not only communicates the Godey novel, but clearly reflects the social attitudes of the time.  It only took three scenes and 45 seconds of film to acknowledge the effect of women in the work place and the continuing struggle of minorities in 1974 America. Having not viewed the movie in twenty years, it further reminded me of just how great the 1970s was for film in America and how far we have fallen since.  Can you imagine what Jerry Bruckheimer and crew would do with a remake of this one?  Hopefully whom ever urged him to butcher "Gone in Sixty Seconds" didn't like classic noire.

When I say it just doesn't get any better than this I do not speak in jest. The original novel, dealing with the taking of a NY subway by an ex-mercenary and three accomplices for ransom, was a wonderful study of urban American life in the 1970's. That was a really good mainstream novel. I dare say this movie does what few movies of good novels ever do - it tells the story even better. I further dare say it trumps another Robert Shaw movie of 1974, the Oscar winner The Sting. Shaw coldly and coolly plays the mercenary who spars with Matthau, playing Leftenant Gah-ber of the NYC transit police, maybe in his best role ever. The movie takes the best pieces of the novel and then adds a couple of twists of its own, just superb screenplay work. The more recent theatrical version is a good workmanlike telling but does not stand up to the classic. Enjoy.

The adventure begins in this movie right from the start. There's no unnecessary lead-ins, no confusing sub-plots that the viewer has to muddle through and keep straight, no particularly complicated characters that we struggle to understand. A group of men hijack a New York City subway train and threaten to kill the passengers unless the city pays them $1 million. It's simple and straightforward and fast-paced and exciting and features excellent performances, particularly from Walter Matthau, who takes control of the situation for the Transit Police as Lt. Garber and from Robert Shaw as "Mr. Blue," the leader of the hijackers.The almost two hours flies by with only a couple of minor weaknesses. There was obviously a feeling that audiences couldn't handle the amount of tension involved and so some unnecessary comedic elements were added. I'm thinking particularly of the portrayal of the lily-livered, indecisive Mayor of New York (played by Lee Wallace) and, although it was only one scene, the reaction of the drunk woman on the train to the hijacking after it was all over. Assuming that they were added to break the tension, neither succeeded - they didn't add much comedy and they were unnecessary add-ons to a very exciting movie. The very last scene of the movie also left me a bit empty. Frankly, I knew what was going to happen from the moment Garber and Lt. Patrone (Jerry Stiller) showed up at the apartment. True, it was only one scene - but it was the last scene, and - again - it seemed to be written with the intention of making the audience laugh, which seemed out of sync with the whole feel of the movie. Still - a great story and a great movie. 8/10

I love Walter Matthau. He always gave memorable performance. This is review is my opinion. The cast is very good as is everything else. This is the best version. It has everything going for it. Why they had to have the board of directors for the Tokyo subway I have no idea. Still holds up to this day.

reviews.review_title: One of the best hijack films
reviews.content: A seriously enjoyable heist movie from the seventies with a brilliant cast. A subway train gets hijacked by four armed men. Mr Brown, is kind of inconspicious, Mr Grey is a total nutter, Mr Green is out of his depth and doesn't want any killing. Mr Blue (Robert Shaw) is their leader and a calculating mercenary. After the train hijacking they get in touch with the subway bosses and demand $1m from NYC. Head of the subway is Garber (Walter Matthau) and he communicates with the villains, but he's an intelligent man. The hijackers end up not being as brainy as they thought and with Grey being a loose cannon their plan unravels.An enjoyable mad better with superb actors and a tight script, it would be remade later with Denzel Washington and John Travolta, a decent effort but nowhere near as good.

A team of hijackers takes hold of a NYC subway car and says that will kill a passenger every minute unless the city pays them $1 million..With a plot like that its easy to see why this movie grabs your attention...but what holds it together is excellent pacing that keeps you involved and wondering what is going happen next. An excellent cast including Robert Shaw, Walter Matthau, and Martin Balsam adds to the fun.. This is an overlooked gem of a picture..not perfect and not a masterpiece but a good solid action drama that will keep you glued to your seat.. on a scale of one to ten..8

reviews.review_title: Great movie with a great score
reviews.content: A great movie from the 70's which just knocks spots off more recent high profile movies of its type. Under rated on every level, the entire cast give outstanding performances, and it makes for a non-stop rollercoaster of a ride.Eat your heart out the 2009 remake, it doesn't come close to the 1974 original.People involved with casting rarely get a mention, but the casting for this is perfect, particularly Robert Shaw and Walter Matthau in the leads.Finally a word about the movie score, which is top notch and again fits the movie perfectly. Years later I find myself playing that score in my head, so thanks to David Shire for that.

reviews.review_title: A very entertaining look at a high tension hijacking. as well as a look back into NYC culture of 1974
reviews.content:
Boy, DID SEEING THIS MOVIE TODAY (11-5-19) on the MGM channel ever bring back some memories!!! I first saw it decades ago shortly after in was released in 1974. I actually lived in NYC for about 20 months, from New Year's 1976 through AUG 1977. And yes, folks, TONS of New Yorkers actually WERE that abrasive, argumentative and downright profane back then. Crime was worse then also. But I must admit that life in the "City" was never boring. Living and working there morphed me into being fluent in profanity.
This film is centered on a strange, weird hijacking ... of a NYC subway car. The 4 Bad Guys led by the unbelievably GREAT actor Robert Shaw (as leader Mister Blue) take over control of a subway by brandishing machine guns. Among the hijackers is ex-motorman Mister Green, played by great role actor Martin Balsam. They have plans to demand ransom, $1 million, which is probably worth over $10 million now, and to kill hostages unless their demands are met. Using the expertise and knowledge of Balsam/Green, they devise an ingenious plan to escape from the subway tunnels WITH the money and without being discovered by the police. It almost works.

Confession - I watched the Tony Scott remake of this Sargent flick with Denzel Washington and John Travolta first. Another - that, in no way diminished from my enjoying this on TV recently. Yes, there are those repartees that are more a norm, them being organic and all, though they were rehearsed, of the 70's staple, that could be found in movies of any genre (with a few not-too- notable exceptions, of course). Yes, like many movies of that period, it looks like 'French Connection' (the first one). Yes, 'Payback' got the 70's period soundtrack right. This one has the pounding score throughout, except when it's all silent for us to get the sound design. Very nice.The plot's the same, with the plan being the same, and the dead man's feature being the linchpin of the gig. It's been a while since I watched Robert Shaw man it up as the suave baddie. He does one more fantastic job, that evokes memories of his other good roles, in 'From Russia with love' and 'The Sting', among others. he would have made a great Marlowe, along with the other Robert.Speaking of evocative turns, Matthau pretty much mans it up too, throwing politically incorrect barbs all the way, while Jerry Stiller is very much himself, and Hector Elizondo playing the kind of character we have not seen him play in a long, long time, wishing he'd had more screen time. Balsam is, as always, fantastic, and his 'tic' (Hic) that's used very much for effect, and a key twist as well, is super- endearing.The focus is on the narrative throughout, and this has to be one of the best edited features out there, and does not seem dated a bit. Mattahu plays the kind of reluctant and recalcitrant hero we have seen before, but the way he kind of eases into it allows us to get into his shoes quite a few times, and there's no doubt about who's actually in control in all the exchanges he has with Shaw, even though things on the surface might indicate otherwise.Not to be missed, and worth repeat viewings. The remake's pretty decent too, but if I were asked to choose, in spite of my fondness for Tony Scott movies, and the Washington-Travolta combo, I'd have to say that the original's the better movie of the two, even though I saw it after the remake.

As you read this The Taking of Pelham One Two Three has been remade by the erratic and attention defeicit director Tony Scot. the remake has most certainly hit cinemas, I'm not one for remakes but this version bearing in mind that their was an inferior made for TV movie bearing the same title, This is a film that no matter what i always sit down to watch whenever it's on sadly the TV showings are in dreaded pan and scan which makes the film unbearable to watch as the 2:35:1 Widescreen composition is gone, what makes this a classic well one just has to take one look at it's cast Robert Shaw as the icy cold leader of his color coded band of thieves (you can see where Quentin Tarontino got his inspiration for reservoir dogs!) Martin Balsam is superb as the mild mannered Mr Green, Hector Elizondo as his not so mild mannered co-Hort, the good guys are led by Walter Matthaua who plays the transit authority official out to try and thwart the villains, and Jerry Stiller as his co worker, also look out genre favorite julias Harris( he played Tee-Hee in live and let die)

reviews.review_title: A hostage situation on a subway?
reviews.content: Maybe not as well known and remembered, recently reborn through the remake, the 1974 Taking of the Pelham One Two Three is a top notch heist flick.Transit policeman at the NY subway command centre becomes a hostage negotiator, when four armed men take over the Pelham One Two Three and threaten to kill the hostages is the sum of 1 million dollars isn't delivered to them within 60 minutes.Garber, played by Walter Matthaw, is an ordinary man who is doing his job without expecting anything unusual, but still manages to stay calm during tense situations, Matthaw clearly plays his role well. The antagonist, Blue, is a surprisingly interesting one, since he's so mysterious, precise and motive-less. Robert Shaw is brilliant as Blue. The only character on the blacklist is the mayor, played by Lee Wallace. Not that he was bad, but I seriously didn't buy it.The movie's forte point was the suspense it created, the unpredictable turns, which may not seem so special today, but had a powerful effect back then.The plot only lacks some backstory - Garber's, but it's arguably a good point, since everything is centred more around the antagonists.The movie is an excellent pick for fans of robbery/heist movies, the actors mentioned above or just those who want to watch underrated classics.Final Score: 4/5 or 8/10

If hearing the Lord's name vain doesn't bother you in the least, this is a good film with terrific suspense and a good foursome of male actors in Walter Matthau, Robert Shaw, Martin Balsam and Hector Elizondo. When I first saw this in the theater almost 35 years ago, I liked it a lot. However, now that the blasphemy part bothers me, this film is a disaster, like the subway-car situation in the story. I don't know if I have heard this much verbal abuse in a 100-minute film as this one, although I can think of a few others that are close. It's too extreme and ruined the movie for me, and it's typical of films made around this time in the mid 1970s. These thrillers had a good "edge" to them but had such a sleazy atmosphere, I can't enjoy them anymore. Also, despite the premise and the trailers, this movie does not have the amount of action you expect you're going to see. Thus, people aren't offended by the language still may be disappointed that this isn't as fast-moving a story as they anticipated.

I enjoyed watching this suspenseful thriller whose action leads up to a great ending. Four gangsters kidnap a carriage of the New York underground (or subway) and demand a ransom of 1 million dollars for the passengers they are keeping hostage. The big questions are: Will the government pay? And how will they get out of the underground tunnels? The plot is well-constructed and sagging only just a little in the middle passages of the film. Especially the scenes showing the sick mayor of New York don't contribute much; director Joseph Sargent might just as well have done without them. The acting is hard to assess, given that the four gangsters (Robert Shaw, Martin Balsam, Hector Elizondo and Earl Hindman) are covered by so heavy prosthetics that they are almost unrecognisable. Walther Matthau, who plays Lt. Garber of the New York transport police, is of course good as always; his look in the last scene is priceless. In sum: a solid 7 stars-rating.

Great thriller-drama. Original plot, well told. Quite gritty and unpredictable, filled with moments of genuine intrigue. Nothing can be forespelled, unlike many Hollywood movies.Some good humorous moments too.Excellent performance by Walter Matthau and Robert Shaw in the lead roles. Matthau is the most unlikely of heroes, and this is one of the reasons the movie is so good. Good support from Jerry Stiller (Ben's father. Yes, he did stuff before Seinfeld...).Much better than the 2009 remake.

reviews.review_title: A clever, yet underrated, NY-un-PC thriller!
reviews.content: Shining a flashlight on un-politically correct New York City in the 1970's, this film has little bit of everything, much like the city it takes place in. Intelligent and unforgiving, the director captures the dearth of the subway system as Walter Mathau, Robert Shaw, Martin Balsam, Hector Elizonda & Dick O'Neill play nursemaid to it, one way or another. The city is a character above and below the ground and is on parade as the hostage drama plays out while a militant 70's jazz score systematically picks up the pulse. There is as much action as humor, but they do not prey upon each other like in today's' action thrillers. They are not simply trying to be cool, but seemingly real... So. who's gonna steel a subway car?

reviews.review_title: Classic Drama mixed with classic comedy.
reviews.content: It is sad that no one knows how to make this kind of movie anymore. It doesn't have flying men in metal suits, no one falls into a canyon and bounces back up, there is no sexual situations every 2 minutes (none at all), no pretty girls that are put into it just to appeal to, well, you know what I mean, (I'll be nice), no explosions, no naked people, NONE of what the kiddies must have today in their movies. What it DOES have, is magic. Walter Matthau offers up his usual fantastic acting mixed with a touch of classic comedy lines of that time. A great movie, in my opinion, is one that when you see it on TV, no matter what part is on at the time, you lock into it and watch it. Every time. This movie IS that type of movie. Sadly, I don't think the generations that came after this even have a clue as to what is actually good, as their requirements/expectations for what they call a "movie" is so distorted today.

Spoiler.  I remember this film when I was a little boy. I always loved action thrillers;films that my mom thought were a little too violent stuck out in my mind.  I remember this film along with the 7 ups, and Race with the Devil as a few on my mom's nasty list.  I thought they were great, but as I watch them now, they seem so dated and do not age well!  The Japanese and female comments would never be allowed now, but what really got me was how they did it so over the top with the bad behavior of everyone.  I work at the post office, and even there with its new lows every year, no one screams and shouts like that.  This made it cornballish, and how could they escape so easily, and the idiot who tries to get on the train, and the other idiot screaming during hostage negotiations is just plain stupid.  The great part of the film is the performance by Robert Shaw, and Walter Matthau were exceptional considering the script they had to work with.  This film is no God Father, or The Sting, so I gave it a five.

This was an incredible big score movie taking place in NYC on the subway. I thought Money Train with Woody Harrelson and Wesley Snipes was the only such movie.Four hijackers... er um subway jackers... take control of the Pelham 123 train. They have hostages and they want a million dollars ransom to let them go. The ringleader is a cold-blooded Englishman that drives a hard bargain. Think Hans Gruber from Die Hard.The movie was fast-paced and full of surly New Yorkers. You had to love it--guys and gals who had little time for some gang holding a subway car full of riders hostage. Some of their attitudes were very welcoming because it was BS-free and others--their penchant for being no-nonsense only made things worse. We got to see the good and the bad of New York hostility and angst.This was a well written movie and well cast with the exception of Walter Matthau and Jerry Stiller. I would say that Matthau and Stiller being cast as lieutenants on the Transit Authority Police Force seemed out of place. As serious as the movie was and as the criminals were Matthau didn't really pull off the serious, keen cop role. Not that he was silly in the role it's just he wasn't that believable.Matthau and Stiller aside, the casting of this movie was still great. It wasn't quite gritty, cold, and mean yet not silly and satirical either. It's the end of the school year and time for final grades. This is a B+.

reviews.review_title: Dated, but in a good way
reviews.content: 'The Taking of Pelham One Two Three' is an old school thriller, and none the worse for that. Featuring no special effects, no beautiful people, no square-jawed heroism and no valedictory moralising, it pivots instead around a simple, brilliantly claustrophobic idea: a gang of mysterious criminals (using 'Reservoir Dogs'-style colour coded names) steal a subway train, and hold the prisoners hostage. The acting is hammy, but there's far more real tension here than, for example, in the recent films in the Bourne series, which are superbly slick but which bear no resemblance to real life. By contrast, this a story whose details you can believe; in some ways its primitive, but it works.

reviews.review_title: Good old fashion crime movie that rocks!
reviews.content: I haven't seen the 1998 tv version of this movie and neither do I want to. I'm probably guessing but I suppose its got a typical 1990s gloss with added subplots and lots of sanitised political correctness.If I'm incorrect then it still doesn't excuse these feeble 90s excuses for "action" films (Speed, Money Train and a host of others), because they're all about as convincing as the Easter Bunny surfing Niagra Falls standing on one leg while singing "This is the Real thing!"It might humour a lot of younger people when they see how dated this film really is but at least New York (and action films back then - French Connection, Seven Ups) had a gritty, realism about it. People spoke as they wanting to speak (rightly or otherwise), they didn't have to take a breath before making a remark that might be deemed offensive in today's overly sanitised society. Watching Pelham is like watching a microcosm of New York life at street level: in computer terms, What You See is What You Get!It could have been so easy for director, Jo Sargent to cast "beautiful people" instead of the heavily thick-set actors of Matthau, Shaw & Balsam. He could have added a romantic subplot with some pretty young thing being one of the hostages wishing her heroic boyfriend cop will jump over high-speed carriages or leap through windows to save her before the bomb goes off with a second to spare (yawn)!But no, instead Sargent plays it for real. The hostages are all typical New Yorkers, remote, insular and yet real people with ordinary human hearts & mannerisms. The bad guys, too, don't have to try too hard to convince us they mean "we're professionals" and therefore "don't f**k with us".Robert Shaw & Hector Elizondo in particular are not visually handsome actors some might say; yet they carry a natural air of menace that a lot of today's "stars" couldn't create without a lot of makeup, method acting & voice training.I have to say I was somewhat surprised with Matthau's role: I'm not saying that it was above his considerable acting talent because it wasn't; just that we all know he is more familiar with the dry humour & wiseguy comedy role movies  with the likes of Jack Lemmon & Billy Wilder.However, he is quite amazing here as the anti-hero transit cop who has to deal not only with the bad guys stealing the train, but also with the subway manager & buddy, Correll, who is trying to keep the remaining train timetables running(excellently played by Dick O'neill). In fact Correll is more of a Lemmon trade-off since there is still plenty of wisecracking remarks being fired off between both men that lightens the tensions somewhat.The action builds at a tactically measured pace: there is no great hurry to move us or the story along too fast. The script is not overworked and the characters (especially the bad guys) are given enough time to develop into something substantial, so that we the audience can get an inkling into the minds of these calculating professionals.The ending (after the dramatic train-run) is a bit of a let down, and perhaps all too obvious and expected. For once, in a movie like this, you got the feeling that these bad guys are way ahead of the cops on a tactical level and would/should win, and yet they....well.....see for yourself.The real bonus though has to be the score by David Shire. Typical 70s anthems with Jazz, moody blues and a really heavy funk theme at the very beginning - talk about throbbing energy - imagine that playing on your car stereo with the bass on number 10 (or number 11 if you like Spinal Tap)!A superb crime film that has all the right ingredients and no CGIs, no overly done special effects, no silly macho men/new age men, no political axe to grind and no 90s superficiality.****/*****

I watched this movie again recently after a number of years and thoroughly enjoyed it.Everything about the movie shines- the settings, script, performances and music. It rattles along at a fast pace. A lot happens in the less than 2 hours running time. Nowadays every "serious" film has to be at least 2 hours for some reason. To sell more popcorn perhaps? Matthau is excellent as the deadpan Subway police chief who tries to make the best of a nightmare situation. Shaw excels as the ruthless mercenary who came up with the plan. Supporting performances from Balsam etc are also top notch.I think a native New Yorker would appreciate the film even more as it is full of NY humour. The scenes with the the panic stricken mayor are very funny and examples of the brilliant humour in the film.Undoubtedly an underrated classic from the typically seventies theme music to the brilliant ending.

reviews.review_title: One of the best action/suspense films of all time
reviews.content: Most likely, the only reason they decided to remake "The Taking of Pelham 1, 2, 3" is because this original version lacked a love story and long action scenes. This film, in my opinion, holds up amazingly well today. That's because it does not rely on action scenes to make it fun to watch. In fact, some of the action scenes may seem cheesy by today's standards, but somehow that doesn't matter here. This film is great because of the characters and how well they function on screen. One of my all-time favorite actors, Walter Matthau, is brilliant here in what is one of his best roles, if not his best. His wisecracks alone make this film worth watching, but that's not the only reason it's good. Robert Shaw also plays the leader of the bad guys very well, without being annoying and over-the-top like most villains. The team of villains is also great in that we really get to know each of them enough to make them interesting to us. The main characters make this film good. It is not, however, a completely perfect film, mainly due to the poor supporting cast. Some characters, such as the guys who work at the train station and police department are good for nothing other than complaining and swearing up a storm! An improvement on these minor characters would have made this film flawless. Nevertheless, an excellent action/suspense movie, especially for its time.***1/2 out of ****

reviews.review_title: Solid and well made crime thriller
reviews.content: An edge of the seat, intriguing crime thriller about four men who hijack a subway train and demand $1,000,000 for the release of the train and its passengers. Walter Matthau plays the slightly cynical transport cop on the case while Robert Shaw is chilling as the chief terrorist, Mr Blue. Indeed all the terrorists adopt colours as their "names", a hallmark later seen in another slick crime caper "Reservoir Dogs". The film builds up to a great conclusion, the very sudden ending being one thats very well crafted indeed.

In the French-connection style of filmmaking.  Exciting, realistic, simple, gritty.  Intense, but never histrionic.  Colorful "New York" characters, beautifully acted.  Spare direction, great soundtrack, and a wonderful on-location sense of utter authenticity.  Today's films seem sugar-coated in comparison.

reviews.review_title: instant classic that did stand the time
reviews.content: What a perfect example how to make a flick without effects. What you see is all real so forget the 2009 remake and pick this one up even as it is 40 years old.This is an instant classic with excellent performances and even a bit of joking in the beginning with the Japanese people. I remember seen it with my dad back in the days when I was a teenager and nowadays that almost everything is available I ordered it and didn't regret it after all. What starts out as a hijack of a metroline in NY slowly turns into a cat and mouse game. The story is so strong that it never bored me at all. Even as I still remember what did happen you just sit through this action thriller and the ride is over before you know it. earlier I told that there were no effects and before people will say hey, there are, well, speeding up the reel isn't an effect for me, what you see happening above ground and in the metrolines is actually filmed in NY. No shaky camera's or over the top shots, straight in your face as it should be done. Perfect, no go take the ride.Gore 0/5 Nudity 0/5 Effects 1/5 Story 4/5 Comedy 0/5

reviews.review_title: Classic New York Grit Thriller with a Top 10 Final Scene
reviews.content: The days when action thrillers were smart and subtle...Terrific performances, particularly Hector Elizondo's gum-chewing psycho and Robert Shaw's honorable mercenary -- his best moment? His brief smile at the decked out black man on the platform. Tense and taut with Joe Sargeant's expert, unshowy direction helped by Owen Reizman's awesome NY camera-work. David Shire's 70's percussive music is a perfect counterpoint to the action. I'm also glad to note that other people here have noted this film's absolutely perfect final shot. How rare is a perfect ending? And who'd a thunk it from a film called "The Taking of Pelham 123"? BTW, the soundtrack is definitely available now...

reviews.review_title: Fast Moving, Exciting Seventies Thriller..What a Ride!
reviews.content: I caught this movie coming on last night on Turner Classic Movies, and not being sleepy, decided to settle back and enjoy a film that I had not seen since I was a boy of eleven when it first came out and my parents took me. I had forgotten what a thrilling, exciting, and often uproariously funny gem of a thriller this movie was, and it still holds up beautifully almost four decades later.I read in the trivia that the producers said that PELHAM was a smash hit in cities with subways but flopped pretty much everywhere else, which I find hard to understand, because you do not need to be familiar with any subway system to enjoy this movie's taut script, edgy direction, brilliant performances, perfect atmospheric score, and the astonishing way it walks the tightrope between nail-biting suspense and laugh-out-loud comedy (The Mayor of New York is a particular joy; looks a bit like Ed Koch and whines about being booed in public, and sure enough, when he makes his obligatory public appearance, the crowd boos. That moment alone is worth the price of the ticket.) Interestingly enough, this film came out four years BEFORE Koch became Mayor; a happy accident, if you will, but one that makes the movie that much more fun. Back to the main plot. I think by now, thanks to the 2009 remake (though God knows why they bothered; you cannot improve on what is already nearly perfect), most people know at least the bare bones of the plot: Four men in disguises hijack a Lexington Avenue line subway train, detaching one car from the rest of the train and demanding a million dollars in one hour or they will begin shooting hostages (a wonderful collection of characters as New York as they can get). The task of dealing with this crisis falls to Transit Authority policeman Lieutenant Zachary Garber (Walter Matthau, brilliant as always), who must rouse the Mayor out of his sickbed (he has the flu), butt heads with MTA official Corell (Dick O'Neill in a splendid performance), and do his usual bellowing and strutting, all with perfectly executed timing, in an effort to get the crisis resolved without the shedding of innocent blood.The villains are a fascinating lot. Led by Robert Shaw in a chilling performance as Mr Blue (they use colors as code names), the crew consists of Mr Grey (Hector Elizondo), a trigger-happy former mobster (is there such a thing?), Mr Brown (Earl Hindman), the group's general gofer, and Mr Green (Martin Balsam in another of the splendid character roles he was so justly famous for), a former subway motorman fired by the MTA and presumably trying to get even, and suffering from a rather noticeable head cold (keep your eye on that).This is one of those great movies that is bigger and better than the sum of its parts. Its parts are nothing to sneeze at (you should excuse the pun), but put together, they create nothing short of cinematic magic; this is easily one of the best suspense thrillers since Hitchcock's heyday, and I think the Master of Suspense would have been proud to claim it as his own.Predictably enough, things do not go as smoothly as Garber would wish; getting a million dollars together in less than an hour is no small feat (demonstrated in a brilliant montage of scenes of hands and machines counting, sorting, and bundling hundred-dollar bills), and Garber's pleas for more time fall on deaf ears. Blue is a cold, calculating killer and completely impossible to turn from his purpose.I won't give away too much more, but at the crisis point the subway car is rigged so that it will go from Times Square to South Ferry (roughly fifty City blocks or so) with nothing but green signals so that it will not only not stop, but will pick up speed and eventually we are faced with a runaway subway car, screaming hostages, police rendered impotent, and a chiller of a denouement that ends at the final moment with an unexpected laugh (I won't tell you what it is; it would be too much of a spoiler).I am a native New Yorker and lived there for more than forty years and rode the subways regularly, so this movie was and is a particular treat for New Yorkers. But you don't have to be from New York, or even familiar with the inner workings of a city subway system, to be captivated by Joseph Sargent's brilliant and exciting creation, with a sensational script by Peter Stone, and Owen Roizman's marvelous camera-work, a particularly notable accomplishment since, this story being set in the subway, much of the action has perforce to take place in the dark or semi-dark.Great ride. Great film. And you don't have to be from New York to love it.

The 1970s was a great decade for New York City-set films. The city itself was on the edge, which probably climaxed when then-President Gerald Ford basically told NYC to go f--k itself. In this trying decade, William Friedkin, Sidney Lumet, Martin Scorsese, among others, made some classic, gritty films. Joseph Sargent, a much lesser-known filmmaker, had his own mini masterpiece with The Taking of Pelham One Two Three.A very simple plot - four individuals--initially strangers--donning glasses, mustaches, and hairpieces, and given fake names based on colors, hijack a subway and hold the city hostage for an hour, demanding $1M. Of the four hijackers, the two played by Robert Shaw ("Mr. Blue") and Martin Balsam ("Mr. Green") get the most attention - and background stories. Blue is an ex-British Royal Army officer who ended up as a mercenary in Africa. Blue is basically devoid of emotions, cool, and calculating - a sociopath. And Blue is a long way from the character of Quint, who Shaw would so memorably bring to life a year later in "Jaws." Green is a former subway motorman who was fired for his involvement in a narcotics smuggling operation. Green is also suffering from a nasty cold, and sneezes repeatedly, annoying Blue and the other two hijackers.Mr. Grey is another psychopath who was kicked out of the Mafia for being "too violent" (although seeing how violence should be an asset for the Mafia, "too reckless" was probably the real reason). We don't learn much about Mr. Brown, the fourth hijacker.Transit police lieutenant Garber (Walter Matthau, fairly relaxed amidst the chaos of the transit headquarters during the movie) is the main channel of communication between the hijackers - Mr. Blue only - and the city. Mr. Blue gives the city exactly an hour, not even one minute more, to deliver the money, in stacks of non-sequential $100 and $50 bills. Easier said than done, but Blue doesn't care. If the city fails to deliver on time, one hostage will be killed for every minute the city is late.Although most of the action takes places under Manhattan, this is still a living and breathing NYC movie. The subway passengers who are hijacked are a cross-cultural graph of the city: Irish, Italian, Jewish, Puerto Rican, Black. And in the mix is an undercover cop who doesn't make his presence known until the end of the film. Why? As Garber calmly explains to his hot-headed colleagues, it's one cop with a handgun vs. Four hijackers with machine guns. Do the math, pal. Occasionally the action moves to street level, and Garber has an exchange with the deputy inspector tracking the terrorists and the train that predates a similar exchange between Jackie Gleason and a Black police officer in Smokey and the Bandit three years later.Regarding the other actors in the film, Balsam is pretty much one note as the disgruntled former motorman, but is the only member of the hijacking team with a conscience. Hector Elizondo, who later appeared in several Garry Marshall comedies, is perfectly hateful as the racist, misogynistic, gum smacking former Mafiaso with the amusing real name of Giuseppe "Joe Welcome" Benvenut.Matthau, who was known mostly as a comedic actor, is just perfect as the cynical, wise-cracking, yet tough when he needs to be, lieutenant. An early running gag in the film involves Garber offering a tour to several Japanese transit executives. Believing none of them speak English, Garber makes some inappropriate comments and ends up with his foot in his mouth when he learns they do in fact speak English. There are more comedic moments involving the highly unpopular mayor, loosely modeled after Abraham Beame.This film has left its stamp on current pop culture, as it is a favorite of Quentin Tarantino, who named his diamond heist crew in Reservoir Dogs after colors, as a tribute to this film. And a remake with Denzel Washington and John Travolta surfaced in 2009. But for a real slice of the Big Apple in all its mid '70s glory, the original can't be beat.

The Taking of Pelham One Two Three (a.k.a Pelham 1-2-3) is a riveting suspense movie that builds on great acting, a fine script, and an amazing story line! Walter Matthau plays a lead Police Lieutenant assigned to stop a group of four men who have hijacked a New York City Subway train. Four hijackers, with characteristics that inspired Quentin Tarentino's Reservoir Dogs, demand a one million dollar ransom within a near impossible to reach time limit, threatening to kill one hostage on the train for each minute that the money is late.An amazing music score captivates the viewer immediately. We are drawn into a character study of people representing diverse New York populations. However the real drama and tension of the movie is watching Walter Matthau and the hijacking leader Robert Shaw communicate and compromise about the hostages and the money in a race against time. Viewers of this film will actually feel as if they are part of this terrible and dramatic experience.The one small spoiler that brings the movie down a bit is in negotiating with the hostages and trying to get the mayor's approval, he says, "This city doesn't have a million dollars." This is one statement that hurts the credibility of this fine film. Even in 1974, when this film was released, New York City had far more than a million dollars if these types of situations were to take place. Having the producers place a higher number for the ransom amount may have helped here.There are other elements of the film that are very real. Authentic subway cars were used during filming, and many of the scenes have very dramatic shootouts in tunnels where you can't be sure who's dead and who has survived after the gunfire has stopped. It are little surprises around every corner that will keep you riveted to this movie till the end.Speaking of the climax, the end of this picture may be one of the most brilliantly written scenes in cinema! Whatever you do, don't bother with the two remakes of this film. There is no way that either of them can hold a candle to this slick action flick!

reviews.review_title: I could watch it again and again.
reviews.content: I saw it in the theater in 1974 when it first came out.   I like it as much now as then.  One of the few movies I can watch over and over.  One scene has me wondering.   It is the scene where Walter Matthau goes angrily over to Dick O'Neil and gives him a piece of his mind.  O'Neil falls on the floor and looks up dazed at Matthau.  I wonder if this was intended or a blooper. The remade TV version on this last year was awful.  I wish this movie would be on DVD.
The taking of Pelham One Two Three is an intelligent action film that is seldom seen today. It is suspenseful, not outlandish. It gets strong performances from the entire cast.

A group of miscreants take control of pelham 123 and its passengers, taking them hostage and demanding a huge financial bailout.
A good film manages to create great tension despite being very linear in its narrative. Great interpretation by Walter Matthau.
Recently was made a homonymous remake, which is also not bad, but falls short of the original.I recommend.

A subway train is hijacked by armed gang, Mr. Blue's the boss, he has an English twang, there's also Grey and Brown and Green, in car one they all convene, uncoupling the rest, that leaves eighteen. A dialogue begins, with those up top, Lt. Garber is a New York transit cop, who's informed by Mr. Blue, of the ransom they pursue, one million dollars is the price for hostage swap.Still a wonderful piece of filmmaking, Robert Shaw perfectly cast as Mr. Blue, the exchanges between him and Walter Matthau as Garber outstanding, all encompassed in a more than believable story that travels without interruption, all the way to the end of the line.

No dreary long expositions, no lengthy bonding scenes, no reaction shots of the masses waiting to find out what happens; just take your music case down those steps into the subway and wait for your train. My God, what an hellacious way to make a movie. And there is one other miracle here: the funny quips are thrown into the noise, and come across as what people under such stress might say, rather than being snarky lines given to Mr. and Mrs. Pitt or Bruce or Mel and Danny. The latter spout dialog usually complete with a smirk; Matthau and the rest are in too big a hurry to deal with the problem at hand. Read the quotes in the header above; none are followed by a reaction shot but rather the film flows around them. And how nice it is to see the head cop not be a rogue, but rather a simple slob just doing his job. He doesn't out-sherlock them and if it was not for one undercover man, he would be a failure, but he gets the job done. Great flick.

reviews.review_title: One of Matthau's best which holds up great 31 years later
reviews.content: This is a great film. Pure and simple. It grabs you right from the start and holds on to you tight all through the film. I saw this on television in the 70's and thought it was amazing and then rented it about five years ago.This film is so finely acted by a cast of really great actors. Walter Matthau proves that he's a very versatile actor in this film. I've heard that he didn't like to be described as a comic, that he liked being referred to as an actor and for good reason. He can play anything. Look at this film, "Charade," "The Fortune Cookie," "Fail-Safe," and "The Laughing Policeman," the latter made a year before this film and a really bad and incredibly dull movie in my opinion.Other actors are great in this film. Robert Shaw is great. Tony Roberts has a great part. Jerry Stiller proves he's more than a comic actor. Martin Balsam, an actor whom I can't remember really getting his due, is great in this film. Hector Elizondo doesn't really get a lot to do.The film really captures the sense of a confined space with the subway. Directing a film in a tight space is probably pretty difficult. The music's great. The film's very well made and very well written - plus it's got one of the best endings of any film ever made.I totally recommend this film. I think you'll really enjoy it.

When Robert Shaw, Martin Balsam, Hector Elizondo, and Earl Hindman board the Pelham 123 train, no one thinks anything of it. They don't appear to know each other, and they keep to themselves - until they don't. Robert is the ringleader, staging a kidnapping and hostage with demands for one million dollars in exactly one hour or they'll start killing the passengers. Walter Matthau is the police lieutenant in charge of negotiations, and with New York traffic, unavailable politicians, slow manpower at the bank, and other obstacles, he struggles to buy time to save lives.Though a fun diversion for the evening, this movie has been remade twice, and this one definitely has the flavor of the 1970s. Also, I didn't care for the screenplay. In particular, the scenes with Mayor Lee Wallace and Lieutenant Walter Matthau felt glib and unrealistic - as though screenwriter Peter Stone thought, "People will think this sounds so cool!" In a realistic situation, the people involved on the other side of the hostage negotiations would never be so cavalier. Matthau would not step away from the phone for a smoke break, needing to be summoned when the kidnapper is ready to talk again. Wallace would not trade witty barbs about his political career when first confronted with the news of the crisis.However, if you like disaster movies with a train setting, like The Incident or Unstoppable, you can check it out. It's definitely entertaining, as long as you can get past the slick screenplay. And if you can pretend someone besides Walter Matthau is the lead, like Glenn Ford or Paul Newman. Maybe it's just me, but I don't see Walter as either the "hero cop" type or the fellow someone would turn to in a crisis.

reviews.review_title: A wonderful 1970s thriller filled to the brim with grit
reviews.content: Pros: Entertaining concept, interesting characters of both big and small roles, unexpected twists in its storytelling.Cons: Abrupt ending.Conclusion: Audiences hoping to expand their knowledge on classic thrillers should definitely keep this one in mind.

reviews.review_title: Great crime caper film with an outstanding cast.
reviews.content: The Taking of Pelham 123 is the type of movie that doesn't seem that common anymore.  The film is not big and showy, it is simply a great 'caper' film that shows both the criminals and the cops in interesting ways.  Walter Matthau is great as usual, but perhaps a touch comedic for the subject matter. His role as a head transit cop brings some levity to the story, without making a mockery of the serious situation. The story concerns a gang of armed men who take a subway car for ransom in New York city, and the police who try to deal with their demands and stop them from carrying out their crime.    The cast also includes Robert Shaw(Jaws, From Russia with Love) as the cool but menacing Mr. Blue, leader of the gang; Martin Balsam, one of cinema's best character actors, as the gang member with inside knowledge of the subway; and Hector Elizondo as the unstable and psychotic Mr. Grey. The story is well thought out and very plausible, and the ending is fun, with a touch of irony. Rent it today!

This has got to be one of the best movies of all time - The story is riveting - a bunch of crooks and a disgruntled sacked train driver hijack a subway train (pelham 123) with about a dozen people on board and they're not afraid to turn their guns on their hostages if their demands of $1,000,000 in an hour isn't met. The cast is amazing - Robert Shaw (best known for Jaws) is Mr Blue the ring-leader of the gang, Hector Elizondo (best known for Beverly hills cop 3) a psychotic former mafia killer is MR Grey, Martin Balsam is MR Green & Earl Hindman is MR Brown. The great late Walter Matthau is Zack Garber the man trying to find the answers has to how they will make their escape as well as bringing them to justice.Great story,Great Acting & Nail-Biting Tension!A must see! 10/10

This film has been imitated, ripped-off and unsuccessfully remade, and every one of them only serves to further enhance what a wonderful movie this is. Peter Stone's screenplay is vastly superior to the original John Godey novel, adding better characterizations and a healthy dose of wit (the scenes involving the bedridden mayor and his aides is a hilarious indictment of New York City bureaucracy; also priceless is Walter Matthau's reaction when he realizes the Chief Inspector is black).  This is one movie where the occasional excesses of profanity seem natural and understandable, and not gratuitous.  But then again, this film has an air of pseudo-believability which none of it's imitators like "Speed" have ever possessed.  There is no girlfriend or wife of the police lieutenant on the train to complicate things; there is no cliche ridden invented romance on the fly; there is no heroic stopping of the train through a death-defying feat by the lead. You just get the sense of how the real-life professionals would try to respond to a crisis like this.Robert Shaw, in his last role before "Jaws", shows what a wonderful actor he was as the ringleader of the hijackers. It is cold, methodical villainy at its finest.

"The Taking of Pelham 1-2-3" is an exciting, suspense thriller involving the hijacking of a subway car one afternoon in New York City.  The four assailants (headed by the brilliant Robert Shaw) ask for one million dollars in one hour or one hostage will be shot every minute they are late.  Walter Matthau as a transit cop turns in one of his best performances as he spends the movie negotiating with Shaw to keep the hostages alive. 
The film is fast paced and thrilling in this race against time. And the final scene between Matthau and Martin Balsam, playing one of the assailants, is a beauty.Highly recommended to fans of action films or Walter Matthau.

reviews.review_title: Excellent suspensers don't need special effects
reviews.content: Extremely tight two hours, full of story, with every word in the script, every visual element propelling us forward. Matthau is an excellently conceived, unglamourous, put-upon, middle-management New Yorker working on the Subway, cast in a straight role but showing his genius for comedy in the scenes with the Japanese visitors. Gratifyingly, we are given in this film the origin of Mr Pink, Mr White etc of Reservoir Dogs, perhaps suggesting a homage by Tarantino, which helps convey the kind of plot-driven genre we are in. As you watch, you sense that the film will allow nothing to interfere with a realistic portrayal: the noises of the underground are deafening, and if he says he's going to shoot, he will.

reviews.review_title: They don't make 'em like this anymore.
reviews.content: If you're going to make an action movie, why would you go and clutter it up with sentiment and other non-action mumbo-jumbo?  It sometimes makes for a truly awkward and out-of-place break in the action (remember the animal cracker scene in *Armageddon*?).  This is a movie that cuts out everything, but the action, suspense, and humor, and is all the better for it; probably one of the best in the genre.Shaw, Balsam, Elizondo, and Hinkman play men who hijack a New York subway train for $1 million, to be delivered in an hour, or the passengers start droppin.  I must admit Walter Matthau is an odd choice as the TA cop who is on the case, but he is totally believable in the role.  There isn't a really dull moment in this movie; it moves right along a pretty good clip. All the actors are good, especially Shaw as the cool and collected leader; for anyone who's only seen him in *Jaws* or *The Deep*, you'll be surprised to see that he doesn't play a ham sandwich in every movie.  Well worth the price of admission, but be careful not to accidently get last year's TV movie version of it; it's got nothin on the original.

I never tire of watching this unheralded masterpiece. The dialogue is sharp and witty, as near to perfection as any film script is likely to get. The cast give flawless, understated performances - everyone of them. It is simply a joy, to watch and listen to. Do not miss a single word!

reviews.review_title: The greatest crime/thriller in the history of cinema.
reviews.content: "The Taking of Pelham One Two Three" (1974), this is another example of what I consider a perfect movie. It's also one of my top 10 all-time favorite films! When I first watched this movie, as soon as I heard the opening theme song I was hooked. Then once the movie began, I was on the edge of my seat all the way to the end. I get those feelings every time I watch this movie! One time I skimmed through the novel this movie is based on by Morton Freedgood, known professionally as John Godey. I thought: "this would make a great movie!" When I got home, I looked it up and sure enough they made a movie based on the book. All I can say is; this is one of the most faithful book to screen adaptions in all of cinema. It followed the original novel story exactly! Perfect story, perfect acting, perfect sets/locations, perfect special effects, and of course a perfect soundtrack. This movie fires on all cylinders, and then some! Walter Matthau is perfect as the main character; Garber, and Robert Shaw is stellar as the main villain. The rest of the cast also does exceptionally well! The story is phenomenal, it will keep you hooked from beginning to end. I am not going to spoil anything else, but the ending is one of the most memorable in the history of cinema. This movie is like an ultimate thrill ride, I can watch it 1,000,000 times in a row and never get tired of it. Without question, I give this movie 5 out of 5 stars on my scale, which equates to 10 out of 10 IMDB stars. If you have not seen "The Taking of Pelham One Two Three", go watch it. If you've seen it already, watch it again. This movie is that good! I guarantee you'll enjoy it. What are you waiting for? Go check out the movie right now. The subway train is leaving!

If I had to remember a movie from Joseph Sargent, this would be this one. I discovered it when I was a teen and have never forgotten it; the day after the airing on a TV channel, the Paris subway - at least the carriage where I was in - stopped between two stations, and folks around me began to talk about TAKING OF PELHAM ONE TWO THREE which was on every TV the evening before. It was in 1979 and in France there were only three channels, and the movie was aired in prime time; so only a few people missed it. That's because of this incident I remind the viewing of this milestone in the hostage thriller history. Robert Shaw outstanding as the cold blooded gang leader, a pure mechanic without any feeling, a character faithful to the John Godey's novel, that I have read ten times, less than the viewing of the film. Walter Mathau also awesome, and I don't speal of Marty Balsam. Tense, taut, tough, a film that you won't forget, believe me. Terrific piece of work.

I discovered this movie after reading a blurb about it in the book "Cinema Year by Year: 1894-2000." I quickly went out and rented it and was grateful that I did. The Taking of Pelham One Two Three is a masterpiece of a thriller and certainly one that is too-often overlooked. It contains a large dose of humor, much of it by Walter Matthau, that helps the film tremendously. And while its plot may seem formulaic at first, further viewing will show that it is anything but. The last scene is especially clever (and humorous!). Kudos to director Joseph Sargent and writer Peter Stone for creating such a brilliant piece of entertainment.

When watching "Pelham" it's easy to see why it was remade twice: a gripping storyline, intriguing characters, an event that could easily happen forty years ago, or twenty years from now. This 1974 version is so well done, from throwing you immediately into the story, to great actor choices like Walter Matthau and Robert Shaw, it's hard not to like – more or less love – this film. It dispenses with unnecessary romantic subplots, and never deviates from the cat and mouse game interwoven from start to finish. Shaw is captivating as the menacing mastermind, and Matthau is surprisingly good as his would-be nemesis. Even the supporting cast from Jerry Stiller to Maltin Balsam (as "Mr. Green" – BIG smiles for all BIG 'Reservoir Dogs' fans out there) to Hector Elizondo are wonderful choices. Sure the clothing is dated as is perhaps some of the Seventies lingo, but it never detracts from the intense story. It really has that 70s movie feel and the external Manhattan scenes are terrific. If there is any negative to be given about this film, the less-than dramatic ending and its subsequent frozen last image could have used an additional Hollywood-styled edge-of-your-seat conclusion. Otherwise, this a movie is well worth the watch.

reviews.review_title: Ginger Peachy New York Thriller at its best
reviews.content: Take a simple hijacking plot, mix in some of the finest actors on screen and you get an underrated and exciting action movie that will absorb you to the end. The film is gritty and does not paint a pretty picture of New York, suggesting that everyone is corrupt, bad-tempered and couldn't give a damn about anyone. No one is happy and it is interesting to see that the hijacked portion of the train coincidentally contains a perfect cross section of society (an old man, a young man, a negro, a prostitute, a woman with kids, etc). This is just nitpicking, and the film does have some good characterisations. The film also contains some wonderful New York banter with liberal use of "Goddammit."  Added to all this is a brilliantly funky jazz soundtrack that really captures the mood of the film. The casting of Robert Shaw as the leader of the violent hijacking gang perhaps started off a trend for US film makers to employ English actors as baddies. Watch it. And if you don't like what you see you can, as Mr. Blue would say, "blow it outta yer ass."

One of New York City's greatest movies. Number 2 on my all time favorite list (after "The Train"---Burt Lancaster). Includes the greatest music score of all time, in my opinion; studio big band delivers the sounds of the traffic and the pulse of the subways, brilliantly carried off. Walter Matthau's greatest movie, backed by a tremendous supporting cast that captures the mood and fabric of New York at that time. A perfect mix of dark comedy (some scenes of which would end up scrapped today---and in fact have, on a rather poor remake of the movie for TV several years back) and dead serious drama. You need just the right type of people in a movie of this kind, and this one is brilliantly cast, in some cases right down to physical attributes---even the mayor (Lee Wallace) resembles Mayor Koch (before he was elected!). Should you see the picture? Some past demographics imply you'll appreciate it much more if you come from the city of New York. But even if your home is elsewhere, if you like action movies that are as realistic as they can be without "over the top" special effects, this is one you shouldn't pass up. It's unforgettable.

The Taking of Pelham 123 is what I call a "clean" movie. No soap opera begging for a laugh, no Hollywood cliches, no it-has-it-all. It is a clearcut matter-of-fact portrayal of believable persons and events - it sticks to the point of the story. Every character stands out with genuine personality. It´s the closest thing to Stanley Kubricks razor sharp filmmaking you get. How marvelous if instructors like Spielberg with free access to funds for making movies could learn from this gem.

One of the best movies of the 70s which never quite got the credit it deserved. Lots of great performances but the stand outs are Matthau as Lt. Garber struggling to deal with the equally good Robert Shaw as Mr Blue, leader of the hijackers. The contrast between these two characters is one of the highlights of the film. Garber is the wise-cracking, world-weary New Yorker - Mr Blue the intelligent, cool, calculating Englishman who somehow still manages to retain an air of English politeness and good manners while being a ruthless killer. This film combines tension and suspense with laughs along the way - not an easy combination - but it works. By the way, I've noticed some comments about Shaw along the lines of him "working hard to sound English". Shaw WAS English and trained at RADA (the Royal Academy of Dramatic Art in London) so I think there's a good chance his English accent is pretty good!

reviews.review_title: one of the better 70's crime films
reviews.content: A New York city transit cop must deal with the demands of subway highjackers and transit authorities who want to keep the trains running.  High tension crime drama with exceptional cast and script. Gritty feel is similar to 'French Connection' and 'Seven Ups'.  (Rating: A)

I had been led to believe that this was supposed to be an exciting, suspenseful drama about the hi-jacking of a subway tray in Manhattan. It is neither exciting nor suspenseful,It was done in a very crude,insulting,offensive manner.Most of the characters are offensive stereotypes. There is a newer version that many are saying is inferior to this to this 1974 effort. I haven't seen it yet I am sure it has to be better than this one.Joseph Sargent a respected TV director is behind the camera here.,Peter Stone adapted John Godoy's novel. The cast is headed by Robert Shaw and Walter Matthau. Neither one exhibits the talent we all know both have.Let us hope that in the new version , Both John Travolta & Denzel Washington do better.Martin Balsam is featured as well,he was always a capable actor.Maybe in the 1970's offensive humour was acceptable,In a supposed thriller it comes across as pure vulgarity.Ratings: ** (out of 4) 60 points (out of 100) IMDb 5 (out of 10)

I was just browsing the web and stumbled onto Roger Ebert's website. I noticed he posted a review for this film under overlooked DVD of the week. I was aware that the film was coming out this Friday, but had no idea that it was a remake. I found the original online and watched it. To my surprise I was very entertained, even stunned.
